bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.]Reed, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench is searching for the original notes and memoranda by Walter Reed in Cuba and asks Reed if he knows the whereabouts of these items. Hench also is submitting evidence of Camp Lazear's exact location to the Cuban government, and any information Reed has would be invaluable.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
3/6/41 - letter,
Mil. Post, come also
August 26, 1940
General Walter L. Reed
406 Winder Building
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Reed:
div1.p:
On October 26, Washington and Jefferson College at
Washington, Pennsylvania, is dedicating the Lazear Memorial Building in
honor of Dr. Lazear, who spendt two or three years at Washington and Jeffer-
son before going to Johns Hopkins. The President of the college has asked
me on this occasion to read a paper outlining the story of the conquest of
yellow fever, and the wonderful work of your father and his colleagues.
I have been working on this for several months and have visited General Kean
in Washington, Mr. Moran in Havana, and Mr. Kissinger in Huntington, Indiana.
You will remember that Kissinger and Moran were the first two to volunteer
to your father for the experiments. I have also had some correspondence with
General Truby.

When I was in Washington, General Kean told me your
address, but unfortunately, I had to leave Washington that evening, and was
unable to call on you to pay my respects.

When in Washington, I tried to locate in the Surgeon
General's office, the original notes and memoranda that your father and the
other members of the commission made in Havana, but nobody around the Surgeon
General's office or the Army Museum seemed to know anything about them. Do
you have any idea where these papers are? Do you have in your possession any
notes or papers of your father pertaining to the yellow fever work, or old photo-
graphs taken in Havana at the time? I shall be most grateful for this informa-
tion and if you would be willing to let me do so, I should indeed like to have
the opportunity of seeing them on some future visit to Washington.

I am particularly anxious to locate Mrs. Lazear, I understand
that she is still living, somewhere in California, but I have been unable to find
out where. Do you know whether any of Dr. Carroll's family still survive? I would
be most grateful if you could either give us their addresses or call me what govern-
mental agency might have their addresses.

You will be interested to know that the Cuban government has
bought a property which they thought was the site of Camp Lazear. As I understand
it, they have already collected quite a sum of money for a memorial building, and
- 2 -
had planned, among other things, to erect a replica of Camp Lazear. Having
studied the published records very carefully it did not take me long to find
that they had chosen the wrong site. To make a long story short, Mr. Moran and
I finally found the true site of the Camp and the Cuban government has asked me
to submit my documentary evidence so that they may re-establish the correct
site. I shall be glad later to send you, should you wish to see it, a memorandum
which I am preparing on these investigations and in connection with the preparation
of this report to the Cuban government, any access to photographs or papers that
you may have concerning the work of Camp Lazear would be extremely helpful.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
